header.title: An Inquiry into the Religious Tenets of the Yezeedees

central_thesis: The text provides a deep ethnographic analysis of the Yezeedee religious system, identifying its core tenets as a syncretic blend of ancient Persian dualism (reverence for a benevolent Supreme Being, Yezd/Sheikh Adi, and propitiation of a malevolent Evil Principle, Melek Taoos) with influences from Christianity and Mohammedanism. The author meticulously details their religious rites, hierarchical sacerdotal structure, and socio-cultural practices, concluding on their resistance to external religious conversion and their strategic use of 'blinds' to evade persecution.

structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the Yezeedees, discussing their origins (Dâseni tribe, descendants of ancient Assyrians), the etymology of their name ('Yezeedee' from 'Yezd' or 'Yezeed ibn Moawiyah' as a blind). It delves into their core theology, identifying Yezd/Sheikh Adi as the Supreme Being (Good Principle) and Melek Taoos as the Evil Principle, emphasizing the propitiatory nature of the latter's worship out of fear. The author provides a detailed account of Yezeedee worship practices, including veneration of the sun, fire, and water, various sacred festivities (e.g., New Year, commemoration of Sheikhs), and communal gatherings. Eyewitness accounts describe the procession and exhibition of the 'Senjak' (Melek Taoos symbol), the role of different sacerdotal castes (Sheikh Nâsir, Husein Beg, Kawwâls, Peers, Sheikhs, Fakîrs), and their unique customs such as specific dietary restrictions (no blue clothing, certain vegetables, fish). The chapter concludes with observations on Yezeedee social character, historical persecutions, and their perceived unsuitability for missionary conversion due to their ignorance and traditional adherence.

key_concepts.definition: An ancient religious community primarily residing in the Mosul district, referred to as 'Dâseni' by themselves and others. Their religion is characterized by a syncretic blend of ancient Persian dualism with elements influenced by Christianity and Mohammedanism.

One of the titles applied by ancient Persians to the Supreme Being, from which the term 'Yezeedee' is thought to be derived. It represents the Good Principle in their theology, often identified with Sheikh Adi.

A central figure in Yezeedee theology, believed to represent the Deity (Yezd) or a supposed incarnation of Yezd on earth. His 'tomb' is suggested to be a myth or symbol, serving as a focal point for their worship of the Good Principle. An Arabic poem, 'The Eulogy of Sheik Adi,' describes him as the creator and controller of all existence.

The principle or power from whom all evil proceeds in Yezeedee theology. He is propitiated out of fear, not love, to avert misfortune. His worship is manifest through specific rites, the use of symbolic offerings (scarlet anemones), and scrupulous avoidance of derogatory terms (e.g., 'Sheitan,' 'laan').

The sacred physical symbol of Melek Taoos, described as a brass bird resembling a cock. It is carried in processions, fixed on a candlestick with seven burners, and is the focus of propitiatory worship and offerings. The author suggests it may be used for purposes of divination.

The sacerdotal caste serving as sacred musicians and poets. They chant hymns at festivals to the sound of flutes and tambourines, conduct funerary rites, and are responsible for many religious ceremonies. They are the most numerous sacerdotal caste.

The ancient Persian religious system identified by the author as the origin of the Yezeedees' dualistic creed. The 'Two Principles' (good and evil) are seen as a fundamental article borrowed and adapted into Yezeedee theology, with Melek Taoos being compared to the Zoroastrian 'ferouher'.

Monuments or shrines erected over the reputed tombs of Sheikhs. They are considered points of indirect homage to the Supreme Being, or symbols of divine attributes/incarnations. Lamps are kept burning nightly in them during commemorations.

The lowest sacerdotal caste within the Yezeedee hierarchy. Their duties include ministering at Sheikh Adi, attending the Senjak during its peregrinations, and collecting contributions for the temple. They are sometimes called 'Kara-bash' (Black-heads) due to their distinctive turban color.

A practical strategy employed by Yezeedees to evade persecution from Mohammedans. Examples include attributing the name 'Yezeedee' to Yezeed ibn Moawiyah, ascribing tombs to Islamic figures like Hasan-ool-Basri, introducing Koranic quotations, and adopting certain practices or identifications to appear less distinctively heretical or to conciliate rulers.

practical_system.description: The Yezeedee religious system, as depicted by Badger, operates on a principle of dualistic reverence, combining direct worship of a benevolent Supreme Being (Yezd/Sheikh Adi) with propitiatory rituals directed towards the Evil Principle (Melek Taoos) to avert misfortune. This system is maintained by a hierarchical sacerdotal structure, each caste with specific duties in ritual execution and communal governance. Practical operations involve communal feasts, pilgrimages, ceremonial ablutions, and the use of symbolic artifacts. A significant operational aspect is the employment of 'blinds' or 'dissimulation' to safeguard their esoteric tenets and practices from external (Mohammedan) persecution, manifesting as false attributions, selective information sharing, and linguistic circumlocution.
tools: Senjak (Melek Taoos symbol): A brass bird-like figure fixed on a candlestick with seven burners, serving as the central idol for propitiatory rites.
Flutes and Tambourines: Musical instruments used by Kawwâls to accompany hymns and festive dances.
Censers: Used by Peers during processions to burn incense.
Scarlet Anemones: Used as propitiatory charms/offerings, especially at New Year, placed on house entrances.
Consecrated Bread: A specific loaf of bread used in marriage ceremonies, dispensed by the Great Sheikh.
Water: Used for ceremonial ablutions at sacred springs and during funeral rites (poured into the mouth of the dying).
Bitter Clay from Sheikh Adi: A specific material used in healing rituals.
Sheep's Blood: Used in healing rituals (sprinkled).
rituals: Direct worship of Yezd/Sheikh Adi: Involves chanting hymns by Kawwâls, often accompanied by flutes and tambourines, performed at major festivals and sacred sites.

Adoration of the Sun: A daily practice for priestly castes, involving kissing the ground with faces turned east or west at sunrise and sunset, particularly solemn during pilgrimages to Sheikh Adi. This is an indirect homage to the Deity.

Reverence for Fire and Light: As cognate elements of the sun, fire is held sacred. Practices include passing hands through flames and making gestures as if to kiss and wash faces with them. Lamps are kept burning nightly in sacred niches or caves near fountains/springs.
Reverence for Water: Fountains and springs are considered sacred. Ceremonial ablutions are performed at Sheikh Adi and other holy waters, viewed as a sacred duty rather than mere purification.

Propitiation of Melek Taoos (Evil Principle): Involves specific, largely secret, religious rites, the display of scarlet anemones as propitiatory charms/offerings, and a strict avoidance of uttering terms associated with 'Satan' ('Sheitan') or 'curse' ('laan'). This is done out of fear to prevent harm.

Procession and Exhibition of the Senjak: The brass Melek Taoos symbol is carried throughout Yezeedee districts. Its exhibition is granted to the highest bidder. Worship involves bowing before it, offering contributions, and striking the breast, with potential use for divination in secret assemblies.

Commemoration of Sheikhs: Festivals are held twice yearly at villages with 'Shaks' (monuments/shrines). Rituals include lighting lamps nightly, and Kawwâls burning incense over tombs on Tuesdays and Thursdays after sunset.

New Year Festivities (April): Involves ceremonial ablutions at fountains, communal feasts (sacrificing sheep), music and dancing, and placing wild scarlet anemones on house entrances to propitiate the Evil Principle and ward off calamity.

Funeral Rites: Include pouring water into the mouth of the dying, chanting hymns by Kawwâls, preceding the corpse with incense burners, and daily mourning at the grave by relatives with incense burning.
Marriage Rites: The groom receives a loaf of consecrated bread from the Great Sheikh, sharing half with his bride to seal the contract.

Healing Rituals (performed by Sheikh Nâsir): Involve slaughtering a sheep and sprinkling its blood on the patient's forehead, covering the breast with bitter clay from Sheikh Adi, tying a string over the left wrist, and specific dietary regimens for several days.

relevant_quotes.text: "THIS IS THE EULOGY OF SHEIK ADI; UPON HIM BE PEACE! |"My wisdom knoweth the truth of things, And my truth hath mingled with me. My real descent is from myself; I have not known evil to be with me. All creation is under my control; Through me are the habitable parts and the deserts, And every created thing is subservient to me. And I am he that decreeth and causeth existence. I am he that spake the true word, And I am he that dispenseth power, and I am the ruler of the earth. And I am he that guideth mankind to worship my majesty, And they came unto me and kissed my feet."

"According to the theology of the Yezeedees, Melek Taoos, of which the Senjak is a type, is the principle or power from whom all evil proceeds, and their religious Services seem to partake much more of a propitiatory than of an eucharistic character. In this respect, their system is in accordance with the natural feelings of man in his fallen state, which lead him rather to dread punishment for his misdeeds, than to be thankful for benefits received. The Yezeedees, therefore, revere the evil principle, not out of love, but from fear, and this reverence they manifest not only by such religious rites as these already described, but by scrupulously avoiding all mention of Satan, and the use of any word implying execration."

"I think it cannot be doubted that the term 'Yezeedee' is derived from Yezd, one of the titles applied by the ancient Persians to the Supreme Being. 'We are Yezeedees,' said Sheikh Nâsir to me on one occasion, 'that is, we are worshippers of GOD.' But a difficulty then arises as to the person of him whom they designate 'Sheikh Adi,' and who there is every reason to believe also represents the Deity in their theology."

"There can be little doubt, but that the Melek Taoos is in substance the ferouher of Zoroastrianism; and I think it very probable, that this Image in used for purposes of divination in the secret assemblies of the modern Yezeedees. The worship of a bird appears to have been a most ancient species of idolatry; it in condemned expressly in Dent. iv. 16, 17: 'Lest ye corrupt yourselves and make you a graven image, the similitude of any figure the likeness Of any fowl that flieth in the air.'"

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant for Western Esotericism and Occultism as it provides a detailed account of a rare, living syncretic tradition rooted in ancient dualistic philosophies (Zoroastrianism/Magism). The Yezeedees' reverence for both a benevolent Supreme Being (Yezd/Sheikh Adi) and a propitiated Evil Principle (Melek Taoos) offers a unique case study in dualistic cosmology and operative magic focused on appeasement and aversion, rather than simple invocation. The author's observation that Melek Taoos might be the Zoroastrian 'ferouher' and used for 'divination in secret assemblies' directly links it to esoteric practices of spirit work and omens. The meticulous descriptions of their sacerdotal castes, initiation-like ceremonies (e.g., milk drinking, healing rituals), ritual tools (Senjak, anemones), and the strategic use of 'blinds' to mask their true tenets from persecutors, offer invaluable comparative insights into the organization, secrecy, and survival mechanisms of historical and contemporary occult groups. It illuminates how an esoteric system adapts and preserves its core identity amidst external pressures, offering parallels to the development and concealment of Grimoire traditions and other mystery schools.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This analysis is tailored for scholars of religious studies specializing in ancient and syncretic faiths, particularly those in the Middle East, and for practitioners and researchers in Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Comparative Magic. It is particularly valuable for those interested in the historical and practical dimensions of dualistic cosmologies, propitiatory magic, the role of secrecy and 'blinds' in esoteric traditions, and the ethnographic study of ritual systems and magical fraternities.
